item.title: 3 Life-Changing Lessons from Meditating Daily
item.description:
Meditation is such a simple act--you just sit in one place and concentrate on your breathing--yet it is also extremely difficult. It can teach you so much about yourself.

Over the years, I’ve gone through periods when I meditated regularly and times when I just couldn’t bring myself to sit on the cushion. Even when I was meditating, I’ve gone through periods when I was the easiest thing in the world, and I just couldn’t wait to sit. Other times, I would put it off as long as possible, then drag myself to the cushion, and every second felt like an unbearable eternity.

Through all that, I’ve learned a lot of really powerful lessons from sitting and breathing. Three of them have helped me in many other areas of life:

  • My feelings don’t define me or my world
  • Discomfort isn't always bad
  • Routine matters

item.title: Lessons Learned from a Year Living and Working in Korea
item.description:
My year in Korea has come to its end. Friday was my last teaching day.

As I have done in the past, I like to look back as this chapter of my life comes to a close and review what I've learned. Putting the experiences into a larger context helps me learn from my mistakes and consolidate my successes.

A lot has happened in my first year of living completely independent of my parents, in a country that is literally on the other side of the world from my hometown. Here is what I learned.

Since Joseph Campbell writes about the hero's journey, I thought he would be especially appropriate to help illustrate reflection on this rite of passage. So, this is a Campbell-themed post.

item.title: Lessons Learned from Walking Dogs and Cat Cuddling
item.description:

item.title: Teacher Appreciation
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1247" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Abhijit Tembhekar on Flickr"][/caption]

Wax on, wax off. - Mr. Miyagi, the Karate Kid (1984)

Warriors are always seeking to grow and learn new things, so it makes sense that we'd have a lot of teachers in our life. As the year comes to a close and I contemplate my card list, I'm realizing that most of the people on it are my teachers and mentors. In the past two years, I've acquired an unusually large number of teachers, of exceptionally good quality, and I realize that all the growth and knowledge I've acquired is largely thanks to their efforts.
